{{good article}} {{Infobox winter storm|name=December 1992 nor'easter |image location=December 1992 Nor'easter.jpg |image name=An [[Infrared#Meteorology|Infrared]] (IR) image of the nor'easter on December 12 |stormtype=[[Nor'easter]]
[[Blizzard]]
[[Winter storm]] |date formed=December 10, 1992 |date dissipated=After December 12, 1992 |RSI=4.88 |maximum amount=~{{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[The Berkshires]] in western [[Massachusetts]] |pressure=985 [[bar (unit)|mbar]] |gust= {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[Cape May, New Jersey]] |total damages (USD)=$1–2 billion (1992 [[United States dollar|USD]]) |total casualties=4 direct fatalities, 19 total |areas affected=[[Mid-Atlantic states]], [[New England]] }} The '''December 1992 nor'easter''' produced record high [[tide]]s and snowfall across the northeastern United States. It developed as a [[low pressure area]] on December 10 over Virginia, and for two days it remained over the [[Mid-Atlantic states]] before moving offshore. In Maryland, the snowfall unofficially reached {{convert|48|in|mm|abbr=on}}; if verified, the total would have been the highest in the state's history. About 120,000 people were left without power in the state due to high winds. Along the Maryland coast, the storm was less severe than the [[1991 Perfect Storm|Perfect Storm]] in the previous year, although the strongest portion of the storm remained over New Jersey for several days. In the state, winds reached {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]], and tides peaked at {{convert|10.4|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Perth Amboy, New Jersey|Perth Amboy]]. The combination of high tides and {{convert|25|ft|m|abbr=on}} waves caused the most significant flooding in the state since the [[Ash Wednesday Storm of 1962]]. Several highways and portions of the [[New York City Subway]] and [[Port Authority Trans-Hudson]] systems were closed due to the storm. Throughout New Jersey, the nor'easter damaged about 3,200 homes and caused an estimated $750 million in damage (1992 USD). The nor'easter increased tides across the northeastern United States for several days due to its slow movement. In New York City, tides reached {{convert|8.04|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Battery Park]], which flooded [[Franklin D. Roosevelt East River Drive]]. Along [[Long Island]], the nor'easter destroyed over 130 homes and left 454,000 people without power. In New England, 230,684 people lost power during the storm. Five houses were destroyed in Massachusetts, and flooding reached {{convert|5|ft|m|abbr=on}} deep in Boston. Further inland, the storm produced significant snowfall, estimated at around {{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[The Berkshires]]. The high snow totals closed schools for a week in western Massachusetts. Overall, the storm caused between $1–2 billion in damage (1992 USD) and 19 deaths, of which four were directly related to the storm. In March of the following year, the [[1993 Storm of the Century|Storm of the Century]] caused worse damage across a larger region of the eastern United States. ==Meteorological history== A storm complex moved eastward from the Texas coast into Georgia on December 9.{{cite journal|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|title=Storm Data December 1992|volume=34|number=12|accessdate=2012-03-26|url=http://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/orders/IPS-6B56BBA2-BA63-47A3-AE32-1D874C5683EE.pdf}} On December 9, the [[National Weather Service]] (NWS) issued a [[coastal flood watch]] in anticipation of the developing storm.{{cite book|first=Margaret|last=Buchholz|author2=Larry Savadove|year=1993|title=Great Storms of the Jersey Shore|publisher=Down the Shore Publishing|isbn=0-945582-51-X|pages=151–157}} On December 10, an upper-level [[trough (meteorology)|trough]] was located along the [[East Coast of the United States]]. At around 1200 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] that day, [[cyclogenesis]] – the development of an [[low pressure area]] – occurred over southeastern Virginia. The cyclone moved quickly northward through the [[Chesapeake Bay]] until reaching a position just west of [[Chestertown, Maryland]] on December 11. By that time, the system had intensified to a [[atmospheric pressure|pressure]] of {{convert|985|mbar|inHg|abbr=on}}, while the parent trough extended from Maryland through the [[New York metropolitan area]] to around [[Cape Cod]]. On December 11, the NWS issued gale warnings and advised for boats to avoid the ocean. The storm turned to the southeast and briefly stalled near [[Georgetown, Delaware]]. This was due to a [[high pressure area]] north of [[Maine]] halting its motion. The interaction between the two systems produced strong easterly winds from Virginia to New England.{{cite book|author=Rick Schwartz|publisher=Blue Diamond Books|location=Alexandria, Virginia|year=2007|ISBN=978-0-9786280-0-0|title=Hurricanes and the Middle Atlantic States|pages=344–346|accessdate=2012-03-16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t5U1CYKwQxcC&pg=PA343&lpg=PA343&dq=december+1992+nor'easter+mid+atlantic&source=bl&ots=shUUaT-FdP&sig=SxQ4mHGTTTJ6zzM2vRZ1SquKbmU&hl=en&ei=ESnOTLTDOsH58Aa5x6zCAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CCIQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=december%201992%20nor'easter%20mid%20atlantic&f=false}} The nor'easter finally moved offshore on December 12, and later that day passed to the southeast of [[Long Island]].{{cite journal|title=New York City's Vulnerability to Coastal Flooding|author=Brian A. Colle|date=June 2008|journal=[[Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society]]|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=2012-03-09|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2007BAMS2401.1|format=PDF|doi=10.1175/2007BAMS2401.1|display-authors=etal|bibcode = 2008BAMS...89..829C }} ==Impact== The storm affected a large region of the northeastern United States from West Virginia to Massachusetts with heavy snowfall, sleet, rain, and high winds. The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] attributed four deaths to the nor'easter, but only included those directly related; the agency did not include storm-induced traffic accidents or heart attacks. The [[National Climatic Data Center]] reported 19 deaths related to the nor'easter, although news reports shortly after the storm reported 20 deaths.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=1992-12-15|title=Storm Strikes Plains; East Coast Bails Out|accessdate=2012-03-15|newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QkJWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gOoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5421,3440283&dq=storm&hl=en}} Overall damage was estimated between $1–2 billion (1992 [[United States dollar|USD]]), mostly in New England.{{cite web|author=Mark Lackey|date=2011-06-17|title=Billion Dollar U.S. Weather/Climate Disasters|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|accessdate=2012-03-11|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/reports/billionz.html}} The storm's widespread snowfall ranked it as the equivalence of a Category 2, or "significant", on the ''Regional Snowfall Index'' scale.{{cite web|author=National Climatic Data Center|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|title=Regional Snowfall Index: RSI and Societal Impacts|accessdate=2012-03-09|url=http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/snow-and-ice/rsi/nesis}} ===Mid-Atlantic=== In the [[Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia]], the nor'easter dropped over {{convert|30|in|mm|abbr=on}} of snow. Officials restricted travel on roads to emergency vehicles only in the state's two easternmost counties. In the state, the storm left 15,000 people without power. In northern Virginia, {{convert|2|ft|m|abbr=on}} of snow stranded 2,500 people in [[Winchester, Virginia|Winchester]].{{cite news|newspaper=The Albany Herald|agency=Associated Press|title=Storm smashes into Northeast|accessdate=2012-03-15|date=1992-12-12|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qi9DAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Vq0MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3509,1829297&dq=storm+new+england&hl=en}} In western Maryland, snowfall totals unofficially reached {{convert|42|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Garrett County, Maryland|Garrett County]]. If verified, the total would have been the highest snowfall amount in the state's history. High winds produced up to {{convert|20|ft|m|abbr=on}} snow drifts, which stranded trucks on [[Interstate 68]]. High winds knocked down trees and power lines, leaving 120,000 people across the state without power, including some without any heat. At least 10 people required rescue from their homes.{{cite web|date=2007-01-08|title=Maryland Winters|author=Barbara McNaught Watson|publisher=Baltimore/Washington National Weather Service|accessdate=2012-03-12|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/lwx/Historic_Events/md-winter.html}} In the [[Washington Metropolitan Area]], the mixture of rain and snow caused hundreds of traffic accidents. The nor'easter struck about 14 months after the [[1991 Perfect Storm]] produced similarly high tides across the region, and only 11 months after another nor'easter in [[January 1992 nor'easter|January 1992]]. In [[Wilmington, North Carolina]], the storm dropped {{convert|1.79|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rainfall, which broke the daily rainfall record set in 1888.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|date=1992-12-11|title=Snow and rain across Midwest|newspaper=The Bryan Times|accessdate=2012-03-15|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Y5RTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fYcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5412,3650857&dq=storm+new+england&hl=en}} High tides damaged much of the dune system along the [[Assateague Island National Seashore]] and about a third of the newly installed dunes in [[Ocean City, Maryland]]. Along the Maryland coast, the storm dropped heavy rainfall, with a total of {{convert|2.90|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Salisbury, Maryland|Salisbury]]; the high rains flooded local streams. At Assateague National Seashore, wind gusts peaked at {{convert|54|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The storm struck shortly after a full moon, and the combination of high [[storm tide|tide]]s and waves breached dunes in some locations. Despite its longevity, the nor'easter was less severe than its predecessors along the Delaware Bay, mostly because the stronger northeast quadrant was over the coastline for one tidal cycle, and the predominant southeast winds were blocked by [[Cape Henlopen]]. However, there were still high tides and flooding along the Delaware Bay.{{cite report|author=Kelvin W. Ramsey|author2=John H. Talley|author3=Darlene V. Wells|date=February 1993|publisher=Delaware Geological Survey|title=Summary Report: The Coastal Storm of December 10-14, 1992 Delaware and Maryland|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR37.pdf|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923214312/http://www.dgs.udel.edu/sites/dgs.udel.edu/files/publications/OFR37.pdf|archivedate=2015-09-23|df=}} In [[Lewes, Delaware|Lewes]], the nor'easter produced a high tide of {{convert|6.33|ft|m|abbr=on}}, which at the time was the seventh highest on record. High tides continued in Delaware until December 15. Several days of high tides caused minor beach erosion and damaged dune systems. In [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]], there was property damage from coastal flooding. The storm produced significantly more rainfall than the storm in January 1992, including a total of {{convert|3.12|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Wilmington, Delaware]]. A station in [[New Castle County, Delaware|New Castle County]] reported a record 24‑hour rainfall total of {{convert|3.25|in|mm|abbr=on}}. The rains caused flooding and the third highest [[discharge (hydrology)|discharge]] on record at Duck Creek in [[Smyrna, Delaware|Smyrna]]. Wind in Delaware peaked at {{convert|46|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at a station along the [[Indian River (Delaware)|Indian River]]. Further north along the [[Delaware River]], a high tide of {{convert|7.69|ft|m|abbr=on}} was reported in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. High winds in the city broke the steeple of a church, and the resulting debris briefly closed the [[Ben Franklin Bridge]]. Hurricane-force wind gusts left about 160,000 residents without power. Heavy snowfall spread across the state, reaching {{convert|37|in|mm|abbr=on}}. [[State College, Pennsylvania|State College]] reported a total of {{convert|18.1|in|mm|abbr=on}}, which contributed to its snowiest December on record. In contrast to Delaware and Maryland, the strong northeast portion of the nor'easter affected New Jersey for several days, producing strong winds and record high tides. Wind gusts reached {{convert|80|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]], which were the strongest winds in association with the storm. [[maximum sustained winds|Sustained]] winds were around {{convert|30|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in the region. High winds in Atlantic City destroyed the windows of storefronts. Along the Jersey coast, the nor'easter produced waves of up to {{convert|25|ft|m|abbr=on}} in height.{{cite journal|journal=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|date=1993-01-15|volume=42|pages=4–5|title=Surveillance of Deaths Attributed to a Nor'easter -- December 1992|publisher=Center for Disease Control and Prevention|accessdate=2012-03-11|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00018780.htm}} About {{convert|25|mi|km|abbr=on}} offshore [[Long Branch, New Jersey|Long Branch]], waves reached heights of {{convert|44|ft|m|abbr=on}}. In [[South Jersey]], the [[storm surge]] struck the coast near low tide, which restricted flooding. The highest tide in South Jersey was {{convert|7.89|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Ocean City, New Jersey|Ocean City]], which broke the previous record of {{convert|7.53|ft|m|abbr=on}} set in 1984.{{cite web|author=Thomas P. Suro|publisher=United States Geological Survey|title=Maximum tide elevations prior to and during December 11–12, 1992, in New Jersey|date=2008-09-17|accessdate=2012-03-09|url=http://ks.water.usgs.gov/pubs/reports/wsp.2499.tab31.pdf|format=PDF}} Further north, the surge coincided with several days of high tides and a [[tide|lunar tide]], causing significant flooding and beach erosion. The highest tide was {{convert|10.4|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[Perth Amboy, New Jersey|Perth Amboy]] along the [[Raritan River]], which broke the record set in 1960. In many locations, the storm produced the highest tides since the [[Ash Wednesday Storm of 1962]]. The storm also dropped rainfall across the state, peaking at {{convert|3.80|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Morristown, New Jersey|Morristown]], along with gusts peaking at 58 mph (93 kph) at Morristown Municipal Airport. The rainfall caused higher discharge rates along rivers. The storm also produced high snowfall totals, including {{convert|14|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Sussex County, New Jersey|Sussex County]]. Throughout the coastline, the cost to replace the lost beach from erosion was estimated at $300 million (1992 USD). Most of the impact in New Jersey was from the high tides, which caused the worst flooding in 30 years in some locations. In [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]], high tides flooded portions of the [[New York City Subway]] and [[Port Authority Trans-Hudson]] systems, leaving them closed for a few days. High tides destroyed portions of the boardwalks in [[Bradley Beach, New Jersey|Bradley Beach]] and [[Belmar, New Jersey|Belmar]], and also destroyed a century-old fishing pier in [[Ocean Grove, New Jersey|Ocean Grove]]. Flooding closed portions of roads across North Jersey, including the [[Garden State Parkway]] near [[Cheesequake State Park]] and six [[State highways in New Jersey|state highways]]. At [[Newark International Airport]], dozens of flights were canceled. The storm left 102,000 customers of [[FirstEnergy|Jersey Central Power & Light]] without power. Damage to [[short circuit]]s caused house fires in [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth County]]. Damage was heaviest near [[Raritan, New Jersey|Raritan]], [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], and [[Sandy Hook, New Jersey|Sandy Hook]] along [[Raritan Bay]]. High winds in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]] destroyed the roof of an apartment; the debris struck and killed a woman walking along a nearby sidewalk.{{cite news|author=Joseph F. Sullivan|title=The Storm's Havoc: New Jersey; Swamped and Powerless, Thousands Flee Shoreline|date=1992-12-12|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-13|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/12/nyregion/the-storm-s-havoc-new-jersey-swamped-and-powerless-thousands-flee-shoreline.html}} Throughout the state, the nor'easter damaged about 3,200 homes, primarily in [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth]] and [[Ocean County, New Jersey|Ocean]] counties, and caused an estimated $750 million in damage (1992 USD).{{cite web|author=Thomas O. Herrington|title=New Jersey Sea Grant College Program Manual for Coastal Hazard Mitigation|publisher=State of New Jersey|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=http://www.state.nj.us/dep/cmp/coastal_hazard_manual.pdf|format=PDF}} Then-governor [[Jim Florio]] declared a state of emergency and activated the [[New Jersey National Guard]]. About 19,000 people were evacuated in six towns in Monmouth County. Statewide, about 2,000 people in 20 towns had to be evacuated by helicopter or National Guard truck. The [[American Red Cross]] opened at least 30 shelters across the state, housing over 5,000 people affected by floods or lack of heat. Damage in the state was less than the nor'easter of 1962 due to 30 years of [[Emergency management#Mitigation|disaster mitigation]], including [[beach nourishment|beach replenishment]], dune construction, and improved building codes. ===New York and New England=== Before the storm's circulation passed the New York area, its associated trough produced sustained easterly winds of 50 mph (80 km/h) along Long Island. Wind gusts reached 77 mph (124 km/h) at [[LaGuardia Airport]]. The strong easterly winds produced high tides in the region that increased gradually after three consecutive tidal cycles; this was due to the nor'easter's slow movement. There was a storm surge of about 3 ft (1 m) at [[Battery Park]] at the southern end of [[Manhattan]]. The same station reported a high tide of {{convert|8.04|ft|m|abbr=on}} above sea level, which was high enough to surpass the sea walls for a few hours. The ensuing flooding submerged portions of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt East River Drive]] to about 4 ft (1.5 m) deep. At least 50 cars were stuck, and some drivers required rescue. Low-lying neighborhoods of New York City were also flooded. High waves canceled ferry service to [[Staten Island]]. A power outage closed the New York City subway system for about five hours. The highest tide in Long Island was {{convert|11.27|ft|m|abbr=on}} at [[Willets Point, Queens]]. The tides and flooding decreased after the winds shifted to the north, ending on December 14.{{cite journal|author=Christopher E. Schubert and Ronald Busciolano|title=Peak Storm-Tide Elevations Produced by the December 1992 Storm Along the Coast of Long Island, New York, with Historical Peak Storm-Tide Elevation|publisher=State University of New York|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=http://dspace.sunyconnect.suny.edu/bitstream/handle/1951/47899/SCHUBE00.pdf?sequence=1|format=PDF}} High tides canceled ferry service to [[Fire Island]], and the only bridge onto the island was closed to all but emergency personnel and homeowners. High waves washed away dunes and severely eroded beaches along the island, destroying over 100 summer homes.{{cite news|author=John T. McQuiston|date=1992-12-15|title=After the Storm; Fire Island Record Tides Are Toppling More Homes Into the Sea|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/15/nyregion/after-the-storm-fire-island-record-tides-are-toppling-more-homes-into-the-sea.html}} On nearby [[Westhampton Beach, New York|Westhampton Beach]], 30 homes were destroyed, and about 100 houses were isolated due to two new inlets created during the storm. Flooding closed all three bridges connecting [[Long Beach Barrier Island|Long Beach Island]] to the mainland.{{cite news|author=Jonathan Rabinovitz|date=1992-12-12|title=The Storm's Havoc: Long Island; Degree of Ferocity Shocks a Place That Is Used to Storms|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/12/nyregion/storm-s-havoc-long-island-degree-ferocity-shocks-place-that-used-storms.html}} Flooding up to {{convert|8|ft|m|abbr=on}} forced about 3,000 people to evacuate from one village on northern Long Island. About 700 homes were damaged in [[Bayville, New York|Bayville]] along the north coast. High winds downed trees and power lines, leaving more than 454,000 [[Long Island Lighting Company]] customers without power.{{cite news|author=John T. McQuiston|date=1992-12-14|title=After the Storm; Long Island; Almost 3,000 Homeless In a North Shore Town|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-14|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/14/nyregion/after-the-storm-long-island-almost-3000-homeless-in-a-north-shore-town.html}} In [[Mamaroneck (town), New York|Mamaroneck]] to the northeast of New York City, a man drowned after being swept away by floodwaters. In the [[Albany, New York|Albany]] area, where the storm was known as the ''Downslope Nor'easter'', there was little snow accumulation during the storm's closest approach due to above freezing temperatures. After the storm moved by the region and the winds shifted to the north, about {{convert|6|in|mm|abbr=on}} fell in the city. To the west of Albany in the [[Helderberg Escarpment]] and the [[Catskill Mountains]], snowfall totals reached {{convert|39|in|mm|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|publisher=Albany National Weather Service|date=2011-02-15|title=Major Winter Storms|accessdate=2012-03-12|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/aly/Past/WINTER.htm}} Heavy snowfall spread across the state, including a total of {{convert|14|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Niagara Falls, New York|Niagara Falls]]. In New England, local TV stations named the storm ''Beth''. Across the region, the [[Northeast Utilities]] power company reported that 230,684 customers lost electricity during the storm, although all outages were restored within three days.{{cite web|date=2012-01-01 |title=Northeast Utilities: Major Storm Comparison |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.nu.com/media/stormkit/compare.pdf |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121115081215/http://www.nu.com/media/stormkit/compare.pdf |archivedate=2012-11-15 |df= }} In Connecticut, the nor'easter produced a storm surge of about 3 ft (1 m), and a high tide of 7.2 ft (2.2 m) was reported in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut|Bridgeport]]. This was the highest tide since [[Hurricane Carol]] in 1954. The rising tides killed one man in the state, and there was also one fatality in neighboring Rhode Island. Along [[Cape Cod]], {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} waves eroded beaches, and evacuations were recommended in two cities.{{cite news|author=Jeff McLaughlin|date=1992-12-13|title=Tidal surges gouge beaches, destroy houses along Cape|newspaper=The Boston Globe|accessdate=2012-03-15|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/61896209.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Dec+13%2C+1992&author=Jeff+McLaughlin%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Tidal+surges+gouge+beaches%2C+destroy+houses+along+Cape&pqatl=google}} The storm destroyed severely damaged two houses and destroyed six houses on [[Nantucket]] http://www.weatherknowledge.com/The_Great_NorEaster_of_Dec_1992.pdf and one in [[Plymouth, Massachusetts|Plymouth]].{{cite news|title=After the Storm; Flooding and Snow Stagger Massachusetts|date=1992-12-14|newspaper=New York Times|accessdate=2012-03-15|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/12/14/nyregion/after-the-storm-flooding-and-snow-stagger-massachusetts.html}} During the storm, more than 20 [[pilot whale]]s were beached along the cape, of which seven died.{{cite news|newspaper=Worcester Telegram and Gazette|agency=Associated Press|title=Whales Beached on Cape|date=1992-12-13|accessdate=2012-03-15|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WO&p_theme=wo&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADEC4A8432D99E&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM}} [[Boston]] reported a peak tide of {{convert|9.35|ft|m|abbr=on}}, which was {{convert|1.05|ft|m|abbr=on}} less than the record set in 1978. The high tides caused up to {{convert|5|ft|m|abbr=on}} of flooding. The nor'easter produced {{convert|27|in|mm|abbr=on}} of snowfall in a 24 period to the west of the city. Further west, snowfall totals reached around {{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}} in [[The Berkshires]], which created {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} snow drifts. The high accumulations closed schools for a week in the Berkshires, and the cities required National Guard assistance to remove the snow. To the west of the Berkshires, strong east winds prevented significant snow accumulation in valleys. High tides extended as far north as [[Portland, Maine]], which reported a peak of {{convert|7.71|ft|m|abbr=on}}. ==Aftermath== On December 17, President [[George H. W. Bush]] declared three [[List of counties in Connecticut|Connecticut counties]] as disaster areas.{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2004-10-18 |title=Connecticut Coastal Flooding, Winter Storm: Major Disaster Declared December 17, 1992 (DR-972) |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2173 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103184141/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2173 |archivedate=2012-01-03 |df= }} The next day, the president declared 12 [[List of counties in New Jersey|New Jersey counties]] as disaster areas, including all of the counties along the Atlantic coast.{{cite web|date=2005-05-20 |title=New Jersey Coastal Storm, High Tides, Heavy Rain, Flooding |publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |accessdate=2012-03-09 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2174 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103164718/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2174 |archivedate=2012-01-03 |df= }} The declaration allowed for $46 million in relief for public damages and $265 million for insured damage in the state.{{cite web|author=Thomas P. Suro|publisher=United States Geological Survey|title=December 11-12, 1992, in New Jersey|date=2008-09-17|accessdate=2012-03-09|url=http://ks.water.usgs.gov/pubs/reports/wsp.2499.sumnj1292.html}} On December 21, the president declared 9 [[List of counties in Massachusetts|Massachusetts counties]] and 5 [[List of counties in New York|New York counties]] as disaster areas.{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2004-10-18 |title=Massachusetts Winter Coastal Storm: Major Disaster Declared December 21, 1992 (DR-975) |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2176 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103184017/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2176 |archivedate=2012-01-03 |df= }}{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2005-05-20 |title=New York Coastal Storm, High Tides, Heavy Rain, Flooding: Major Disaster Declared December 21, 1992 (DR-974) |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2175 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103160050/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2175 |archivedate=2012-01-03 |df= }} On January 15, 1993, [[Sussex County, Delaware]] was also declared a disaster area.{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2004-10-14 |title=Delaware Severe Coastal Storm, Flooding: Major Disaster Declared January 15, 1993 (DR-976) |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2177 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120105173916/http://www.fema.gov/news/eventcounties.fema?id=2177 |archivedate=2012-01-05 |df= }} Across the nor'easter's path, 25,142 people received assistance from [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]], equating to $346,150,356 in federal aid.{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency |date=2012-03-14 |title=Significant Flood Events 1978 - January 31, 2012 |accessdate=2012-03-14 |url=http://www.fema.gov/business/nfip/statistics/sign1000.shtm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080201121723/http://www.fema.gov/business/nfip/statistics/sign1000.shtm |archivedate=2008-02-01 |df= }} Only three months after the nor'easter struck, another nor'easter caused more severe damage across a larger region of the eastern United States. The March nor'easter, known as the [[1993 Storm of the Century|Storm of the Century]], killed 310 people and left over $1.5 billion in damage (1993 USD). ==See also== *[[1991 Perfect Storm]] *[[January 1992 nor'easter]] *[[1993 Storm of the Century]] *[[Hurricane Sandy]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{United States winter storms}} [[Category:1992 disasters in the United States|December 1992 nor'easter]] [[Category:1992 meteorology|December 1992 nor'easter]] [[Category:Nor'easters|December 1992 nor'easter]] [[Category:December 1992 events]]

In [[Norse mythology]], '''''Fimbulvetr''''' (or ''fimbulvinter''), commonly rendered in [[English language|English]] as '''Fimbulwinter''', is the immediate prelude to the events of [[Ragnarök]]. It means "great winter".
==Summary== Fimbulwinter is the harsh winter that precedes the end of the world and puts an end to all life on Earth. Fimbulwinter is three successive winters, when snow comes in from all directions, without any intervening summer. Then, there will be innumerable wars.
The event is described primarily in the ''[[Poetic Edda]]''. In the poem ''[[Vafþrúðnismál]]'', [[Odin]] poses the question to [[Vafþrúðnir]] as to who of mankind will survive the Fimbulwinter. Vafþrúðnir responds that [[Líf and Lífþrasir]] will survive and that they will live in the forest of [[Hoddmímis holt]].
The mythology might be related to the [[extreme weather events of 535–536]], which resulted in a notable drop in temperature across northern Europe. There have also been several popular ideas about whether or not the particular piece of mythology has a connection to the [[climate change]] that occurred in the Nordic countries at the end of the [[Nordic Bronze Age]] from about 650 BC. Before that climate change, the Nordic countries were considerably warmer.<ref>Ström, Folke: ''Nordisk Hedendom'', [[Studentlitteratur]], Lund 2005, {{ISBN|91-44-00551-2}} (first published 1961) among others, refer to the climate change theory.</ref>
In [[Denmark]], [[Norway]], [[Sweden]] and other [[Nordic countries]], the term ''fimbulvinter'' is still used to refer to an unusually cold and harsh winter.<ref name="saob" />
==Etymology== Fimbulvetr comes from [[Old Norse]], meaning "awful, great winter". The prefix "fimbul" means "the great/big" so the correct interpretation of the word is "the great winter".<ref name="saob">[[Svenska Akademiens Ordbok]], entry for ''Fimbulvinter'' [http://g3.spraakdata.gu.se/saob/show.phtml?filenr=1/68/17365.html]</ref>
==See also== *[[Eschatology]] *[[Fimbulwinter (band)]] *[[Nuclear winter]] *[[Volcanic winter]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Other sources== *Gunn, Joel (2000). ''The Years Without Summer: Tracing A.D. 536 and its Aftermath'' (British Archaeological Reports International. Oxford, England: Archaeopress) {{ISBN|1-84171-074-1}} *Keys, David Patrick (2000). ''Catastrophe: An Investigation into the Origins of the Modern World.'' (New York: Ballantine Pub) {{ISBN|0-345-40876-4}}. *Larrington, Carolyne (Trans.) (1999). ''The Poetic Edda'' (Oxford World's Classics) {{ISBN|0-19-283946-2}} *[[John Lindow|Lindow, John]] (2001). ''Norse Mythology: A Guide to the Gods, Heroes, Rituals, and Beliefs'' (Oxford University Press) {{ISBN|0-19-515382-0}} *Orchard, Andy (1997). ''Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend'' (Cassell) {{ISBN|0-304-34520-2}}
{{Norse mythology}}

revision.comment: -, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: atleast → at least, However → However, (2)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | Watchedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = | Name = helium dimer | ImageFile= | ImageSize= | ImageFileL1 = | ImageAltL1 = | ImageFileR1 = | ImageAltR1 = | Reference = | IUPACName = | OtherNames = dihelium |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | ChemSpiderID1 = | ChemSpiderID1_Ref = | ChemSpiderID1_Comment = | PubChem = | InChI1 = 1S/He2/c1-2 | InChIKey1 = GHVQTHCLRQIINU-UHFFFAOYSA-N | InChI1_Comment = <ref>{{cite web|url=http://chem.sis.nlm.nih.gov/chemidplus/rn/12184-98-4|title=Substance Name: Dihelium|work=Toxnet}}</ref> | SMILES1 = [He][He] | SMILES1_Comment = | CASNo1_Ref = {{cascite|correct|??}} | CASNo1 = 12184-98-4 | CASNo1_Comment = | ChEBI = 33685 | Gmelin = 48 }} |Section3={{Chembox Properties | Appearance = colorless gas | Formula = He<sub>2</sub> | MolarMass = 8.0052 g/mol }} |Section4={{Chembox Thermochemistry | DeltaHf = 1.1×10<sup>−5</sup> kcal/mol. | DeltaHc = | Entropy = }} |Section9={{Chembox Related | OtherFunction_label = van der Waals molecules | OtherFunction = [[LiHe]] [[NeHe2|NeHe<sub>2</sub>]] [[Helium trimer|He<sub>3</sub>]] | OtherCompounds = }} }} The '''helium dimer''' is a [[van der Waals molecule]] with formula He<sub>2</sub> consisting of two [[helium]] [[atom]]s.<ref name=s94/> This molecule is the largest with two atoms, and is very weakly bound together. The bond is so weak that it will break if the molecule rotates, or vibrates too much. It can only exist at very low [[cryogenic]] temperatures.
Two excited helium atoms can also bond to each other in a form called an [[excimer]]. This was discovered from a spectrum of helium that contained bands first seen in 1912. Written as He<sub>2</sub><sup>*</sup> with the * meaning an excited state, it is the first known [[Rydberg molecule]].<ref name=Raunhardt009>{{cite thesis|last1=Raunhardt|first1=Matthias|title=Generation and spectroscopy of atoms and molecules in metastable states|date=2009|page=84|url=http://e-collection.library.ethz.ch/eserv/eth:41903/eth-41903-02.pdf}}</ref>
Dihelium ions also exist with a negative, positive and double positive charge. Two helium atoms can be confined together without bonding in the cage of a [[fullerene]].
==Molecule== Based on [[molecular orbital theory]], He<sub>2</sub> should not exist, and a chemical bond cannot form between the atoms. However, the [[van der Waals force]] exists between helium atoms as shown by the existence of [[liquid helium]], and at a certain range of distances between atoms the attraction exceeds the repulsion. So a molecule composed of two helium atoms bound by the van der Waals force can exist.<ref name=kol04>{{cite journal|last1=Kolganova|first1=Elena|last2=Motovilov|first2=Alexander|last3=Sandhas|first3=Werner|title=Scattering length of the helium-atom–helium-dimer collision|journal=Physical Review A|date=November 2004|volume=70|issue=5|pages=052711|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.70.052711|bibcode=2004PhRvA..70e2711K|arxiv=physics/0408019}}</ref> The existence of this molecule was proposed as early as 1930.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Glockler|first1=Geo.|title=Complex formation|journal=Transactions of the Faraday Society|date=1937|volume=33|pages=224|doi=10.1039/TF9373300224|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/1937/tf/tf9373300224}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
He<sub>2</sub> is the largest known molecule of two atoms when in its [[ground state]], due to its extremely long bond length.<ref name=kol04/> The He<sub>2</sub> molecule has a large separation distance between the atoms of about 5200 [[picometre|pm]] (= 52 [[ångström]]). This is the largest for a [[diatomic molecule]] without ro-[[vibronic]] excitation. The [[binding energy]] is only about 1.3 mK, 10<sup>−7</sup>eV<ref name=nada/><ref name=gris>{{cite journal|last1=Grisenti|first1=R.|last2=Schöllkopf|first2=W.|last3=Toennies|first3=J.|last4=Hegerfeldt|first4=G.|last5=Köhler|first5=T.|last6=Stoll|first6=M.|title=Determination of the Bond Length and Binding Energy of the Helium Dimer by Diffraction from a Transmission Grating|journal=Physical Review Letters|date=September 2000|volume=85|issue=11|pages=2284–2287|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.2284|bibcode=2000PhRvL..85.2284G|pmid=10977992}}</ref> or 1.1×10<sup>−5</sup> kcal/mol,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Toennies|first1=J. Peter|title=Spectroscopy without Photons: Diffraction of Weakly Bound Complexes from Nano-Gratings|url=https://molspect.chemistry.ohio-state.edu/institute/toennies-abstract.htm}}</ref> or 150 nanoelectron Volts.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zeller|first1=S.|last2=Kunitski|first2=M.|last3=Voigtsberger|first3=J.|last4=Kalinin|first4=A.|last5=Schottelius|first5=A.|last6=Schober|first6=C.|last7=Waitz|first7=M.|last8=Sann|first8=H.|last9=Hartung|first9=A.|last10=Bauer|first10=T.|last11=Pitzer|first11=M.|last12=Trinter|first12=F.|last13=Goihl|first13=C.|last14=Janke|first14=C.|last15=Richter|first15=M.|last16=Kastirke|first16=G.|last17=Weller|first17=M.|last18=Czasch|first18=A.|last19=Kitzler|first19=M.|last20=Braune|first20=M.|last21=Grisenti|first21=R. E.|last22=Schöllkopf|first22=W.|last23=Schmidt|first23=L. Ph H.|last24=Schöffer|first24=M.|last25=Williams|first25=J. B.|last26=Jahnke|first26=T.|last27=Dörner|first27=R.|title=Imaging the He2 quantum halo state using a free electron laser|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=20 December 2016|volume=113|issue=51|pages=14651–14655|doi=10.1073/pnas.1610688113|issn=0027-8424|arxiv=1601.03247|bibcode=2016PNAS..11314651Z}}</ref> The bond is 5000 times weaker than the covalent bond in the hydrogen molecule.<ref name=cerpa000/>
Both helium atoms in the dimer can be [[ionized]] by a single [[photon]] with energy 63.86 eV. The proposed mechanism for this [[double ionization]] is that the photon ejects an [[electron]] from one atom, and then that electron hits the other helium atom and ionizes that as well.<ref name=Have10>{{cite journal|last1=Havermeier|first1=T.|last2=Jahnke|first2=T.|last3=Kreidi|first3=K.|last4=Wallauer|first4=R.|last5=Voss|first5=S.|last6=Schöffler|first6=M.|last7=Schössler|first7=S.|last8=Foucar|first8=L.|last9=Neumann|first9=N.|last10=Titze|first10=J.|last11=Sann|first11=H.|last12=Kühnel|first12=M.|last13=Voigtsberger|first13=J.|last14=Malakzadeh|first14=A.|last15=Sisourat|first15=N.|last16=Schöllkopf|first16=W.|last17=Schmidt-Böcking|first17=H.|last18=Grisenti|first18=R. E.|last19=Dörner|first19=R.|title=Single Photon Double Ionization of the Helium Dimer|journal=Physical Review Letters|date=April 2010|volume=104|issue=15|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.104.153401|bibcode=2010PhRvL.104o3401H|pmid=20481987|page=153401|arxiv=1006.2667}}</ref> The dimer then explodes as two helium [[cation]]s ions repel each other with the same speed but opposite directions.<ref name=Have10/>
A dihelium molecule bound by Van der Waals forces was first proposed by John Clarke Slater in 1928.<ref name=slater28>{{cite journal|last1=Slater|first1=J.|title=The Normal State of Helium|journal=Physical Review|date=September 1928|volume=32|issue=3|pages=349–360|doi=10.1103/PhysRev.32.349|bibcode=1928PhRv...32..349S}}</ref>
==Formation== The helium dimer can be formed in small amounts when helium gas expands and cools as it passes through a nozzle in a gas beam.<ref name=s94>{{cite journal |last1=Schöllkopf|first1=W|last2=Toennies|first2=JP|title=Nondestructive mass selection of small van der waals clusters|journal=Science|date=25 November 1994|volume=266|issue=5189|pages=1345–8|pmid=17772840|doi=10.1126/science.266.5189.1345|bibcode=1994Sci...266.1345S}}</ref> Only the isotope <sup>4</sup>He can form molecules like this; <sup>4</sup>He<sup>3</sup>He and <sup>3</sup>He<sup>3</sup>He do not exist, as they do not have a stable [[bound state]].<ref name=nada>{{cite thesis|title=Spectroscopic Detection of the Lithium Helium (LiHe) van der Waals Molecule|first1=Nada Ahmed|last1=Al Taisan|date=May 2013|url=http://www.physics.unr.edu/xap/pubs/Nada_Al_Taisan_thesis_2013.pdf}}</ref> The amount of the [[dimer (chemistry)|dimer]] formed in the gas beam is of the order of one percent.<ref name=Have10/>
==Molecular ions== He<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> is a related ion bonded by a half [[covalent bond]]. It can be formed in a helium electrical discharge. It recombines with electrons to form an electronically excited He<sub>2</sub>(''a''<sup>3</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>''u''</sub>) [[excimer]] molecule.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Callear|first1=A. B.|last2=Hedges|first2=R. E. M.|title=Metastability of Rotationally Hot Dihelium at 77° K|journal=Nature|date=16 September 1967|volume=215|issue=5107|pages=1267–1268|doi=10.1038/2151267a0|bibcode=1967Natur.215.1267C}}</ref> Both of these molecules are much smaller with more normally sized interatomic distances.
The helium dication dimer He<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup> is extremely repulsive and would release much energy when it dissociated, around 835 kJ/mol.<ref name=guilhe2p>{{cite journal |last1=Guilhaus|first1=Michael|last2=Brenton|first2=A. Gareth|last3=Beynon|first3=John H.|last4=Rabrenović|first4=Mila|last5=von Ragué Schleyer|first5=Paul|title=He<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup>, the experimental detection of a remarkable molecule|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications|date=1985|issue=4|pages=210|doi=10.1039/C39850000210}}</ref> Dynamical stability of the ion was predicted by [[Linus Pauling]].<ref name=pH22pp>{{cite journal|last1=Pauling|first1=Linus|title=The Normal State of the Helium Molecule-Ions He<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> and He<sub>2</sub><sup>++</sup>|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|date=1933|volume=1|issue=1|pages=56|doi=10.1063/1.1749219|url=http://scarc.library.oregonstate.edu/coll/pauling/bond/notes/sci3.002.6.html|bibcode=1933JChPh...1...56P}}</ref> An energy barrier of 33.2 kcal/mol prevents immediate decay. This ion is isoelectronic with the hydrogen molecule.<ref name=Olah>{{cite book |last1=Olah|first1=George A.|last2=Klumpp|first2=Douglas A.|title=Superelectrophiles and Their Chemistry|page=12|url=https://books.google.com/?id=hM3BqVkt-tAC&pg=PR12|accessdate=19 February 2015|isbn=9780470185117|date=2008-01-03}}</ref><ref name=dun72>{{cite journal|last1=Dunitz|first1=J. D.|last2=Ha|first2=T. K.|title=Non-empirical SCF calculations on hydrogen-like molecules: the effect of nuclear charge on binding energy and bond length|journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Chemical Communications|date=1972|issue=9|pages=568|doi=10.1039/C39720000568|url=http://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/1972/c3/c39720000568}}</ref> He<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup> is the smallest possible molecule with a double positive charge. It is detectable using mass spectroscopy.<ref name=guilhe2p/><ref name=guil984>{{cite journal|last1=Guilhaus|first1=M.|last2=Brenton|first2=A. G.|last3=Beynon|first3=J. H.|last4=Rabrenovic|first4=M.|last5=Schleyer|first5=P. von Rague|title=First observation of He<sub>2</sub><sup>2+</sup>: charge stripping of He<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> using a double-focusing mass spectrometer|journal=Journal of Physics B: Atomic and Molecular Physics|date=14 September 1984|volume=17|issue=17|pages=L605–L610|doi=10.1088/0022-3700/17/17/010|bibcode=1984JPhB...17L.605G}}</ref>
The negative helium dimer He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> is metastable and was discovered by Bae, Coggiola and Peterson in 1984 by passing He<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> through [[cesium]] vapor.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bae|first=Y. K.|last2=Coggiola|first2=M. J.|last3=Peterson|first3=J. R.|date=1984-02-27|title=Observation of the Molecular Helium Negative Ion He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.52.747|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=52|issue=9|pages=747–750|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.52.747|via=|bibcode=1984PhRvL..52..747B}}</ref> Subsequently, H. H. Michels theoretically confirmed its existence and concluded that the <sup>4</sup>Π<sub>g</sub> state of He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> is bound relative to the a<sup>2</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>u</sub> state of He<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Michels|first=H. H.|date=1984-04-16|title=Electronic Structure of the Helium Molecular Anion He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>|url=https://link.aps.org/doi/10.1103/PhysRevLett.52.1413|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=52|issue=16|pages=1413–1416|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.52.1413|bibcode=1984PhRvL..52.1413M}}</ref> The calculated electron affinity is 0.233 eV compared to 0.077 eV for the He<sup>−</sup>[<sup>4</sup>P<sup>∘</sup>] ion. The He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> decays through the long-lived 5/2g component with τ∼350 μsec and the much shorter-lived 3/2g, ½g components with τ∼10 μsec. The <sup>4</sup>Π<sub>g</sub> state has a 1σ<sup>2</sup><sub>g</sub> 1σ<sub>u</sub>2σ<sub>g</sub>2π<sub>u</sub> electronic configuration, its electron affinity E is 0.18±0.03eV, and its lifetime is 135±15 μsec; only the v=0 vibrational state is responsible for this long-lived state.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andersen|first=T.|date=1995|title=Lifetimes of negative ions determined in a storage ring|url=http://stacks.iop.org/1402-4896/1995/i=T59/a=031|journal=Physica Scripta|language=en|volume=1995|issue=T59|pages=230|doi=10.1088/0031-8949/1995/T59/031|issn=1402-4896|bibcode=1995PhST...59..230A}}</ref>
The molecular helium anion is also found in liquid helium that has been excited by electrons with an energy level higher than 22 eV. This takes place firstly by penetration of liquid He, taking 1.2 eV, followed by excitation of a He atom electron to the <sup>3</sup>P level, which takes 19.8 eV. The electron can then combine with another helium atom and the excited helium atom to form He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup>. He<sub>2</sub><sup>−</sup> repels helium atoms, and so has a void around it. It will tend to migrate to a surface.<ref name=roca2015>{{cite journal|last1=Rodríguez-Cantano|first1=Rocío|last2=González-Lezana|first2=Tomás|last3=Villarreal|first3=Pablo|last4=Gianturco|first4=Franco A.|title=A configurational study of helium clusters doped with He<sup>∗−</sup> and He<sub>2</sub><sup>∗−</sup>|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|date=14 March 2015|volume=142|issue=10|pages=104303|doi=10.1063/1.4913958|pmid=25770536|bibcode=2015JChPh.142j4303R}}</ref>
==Excimers== In a normal helium atom two electrons are found in the 1s orbital. However, if sufficient energy is added, one electron can be elevated to a higher energy level. This high energy electron can become a valence electron, and the electron that remains in the 1s orbital is a core electron. Two excited helium atoms can react with a covalent bond to form a molecule called '''dihelium''' that lasts for short times of the order of a microsecond up to second or so.<ref name=Raunhardt009/> Excited helium atoms in the 2<sup>3</sup>S state can last for up to an hour, and react like alkali metal atoms.<ref name=Vrin002>{{cite journal |last1=Vrinceanu|first1=D.|last2=Sadeghpour|first2=H.|title=He(1 ^{1}S)–He(2 ^{3}S) collision and radiative transition at low temperatures|journal=Physical Review A|date=June 2002|volume=65|issue=6|pages=062712|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.65.062712|bibcode=2002PhRvA..65f2712V}}</ref>
The first clues that dihelium exists were noticed in 1900 when W. Heuse observed a band spectrum in a helium discharge. However, no information about the nature of the spectrum was published. Independently E. Goldstein from Germany and W. E. Curtis from London published details of the spectrum in 1913.<ref name=curtis13>{{cite journal|last1=Curtis|first1=W. E.|title=A New Band Spectrum Associated with Helium |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A|date=19 August 1913|volume=89|issue=608|pages=146–149|doi=10.1098/rspa.1913.0073|jstor=93468|bibcode=1913RSPSA..89..146C}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Goldstein|first1=E.|title=Über ein noch nicht beschriebenes, anscheinend dem Helium angehörendes Spektrum|journal=Verhandlungen der Physikalischen Gessellschaft |date=1913|volume=15|issue=10|pages=402–412}}</ref> Curtis was called away to military service in World War I, and the study of the spectrum was continued by [[Alfred Fowler]]. Fowler recognised that the double headed bands fell into two sequences analogous to [[principal series|principal]] and [[diffuse series]] in line spectra.<ref name=Fowler15>{{cite journal|last1=Fowler|first1=Alfred|title=A New Type of Series in the Band Spectrum Associated with Helium|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London. Series A|date=1 March 1915|volume=91|issue=627|pages=208–216|doi=10.1098/rspa.1915.0011|jstor=93423|bibcode=1915RSPSA..91..208F}}</ref>
The emission band spectrum shows a number of bands that degrade towards the red, meaning that the lines thin out and the spectrum weakens towards the longer wavelengths. Only one band with a green [[band head]] at 5732 Å degrades towards the violet. Other strong band heads are at 6400 (red), 4649, 4626, 4546, 4157.8, 3777, 3677, 3665, 3356.5, and 3348.5 Å. There are also some headless bands and extra lines in the spectrum.<ref name=curtis13/> Weak bands are found with heads at 5133 and 5108.<ref name=Fowler15/>
If the valence electron is in 2s 3s or 3d, a <sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state results, and if in 2p 3p or 4p, a <sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub> state results.<ref name=Guber72/> The ground state is X<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub><sup>+</sup>.<ref name=Kriste89>{{cite journal|last1=Kristensen|first1=Martin|last2=Keiding|first2=Søren R.|last3=van der Zande|first3=Wim J.|title=Lifetime determination of the long-lived B 1Πg state in He2* by photofragment spectroscopy|journal=Chemical Physics Letters|date=December 1989|volume=164|issue=6|pages=600–604|doi=10.1016/0009-2614(89)85266-2|bibcode=1989CPL...164..600K}}</ref>
The three lowest triplet states of He<sub>2</sub> have designations a<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub>, b<sup>3</sup>Π<sub>g</sub> and c<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub>.<ref name=Hazell95>{{cite journal|last1=Hazell|first1=I.|last2=Norregaard|first2=A.|last3=Bjerre|first3=N.|title=Highly Excited Rotational and Vibrational Levels of the Lowest Triplet States of He2: Level Positions and Fine Structure|journal=Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy|date=July 1995 |volume=172|issue=1|pages=135–152|doi=10.1006/jmsp.1995.1162|bibcode=1995JMoSp.172..135H}}</ref> The a<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state with no vibration (''v''=0) has a long metastable lifetime of 18 s, much longer than the lifetime for other states or inert gas excimers.<ref name=Raunhardt009/> The explanation is that the a<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state has no electron orbital angular momentum, as all the electrons are in S orbitals for the helium state.<ref name=Raunhardt009/>
The lower lying singlet states of He<sub>2</sub> are A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub>, B<sup>1</sup>Π<sub>g</sub> and C<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub>.<ref name=Focsa98>{{cite journal |last1=Focsa|first1=C.|last2=Bernath|first2=P.F.|last3=Colin|first3=R.|title=The Low-Lying States of He2|journal=Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy|date=September 1998|volume=191|issue=1|pages=209–214|doi=10.1006/jmsp.1998.7637|bibcode=1998JMoSp.191..209F}}</ref> The excimer molecules are much smaller and more tightly bound than the van der Waals bonded helium dimer. For the A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state the binding energy is around 2.5 eV, with a separation of the atoms of 103.9 pm. The C<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub> state has a binding energy 0.643 eV and the separation between atoms is 109.1 pm.<ref name=Guber72>{{cite journal|last1=Guberman|first1=S.L.|last2=Goddard|first2=W.A.|title=On the origin of energy barriers in the excited states of He2|journal=Chemical Physics Letters|date=15 June 1972 |volume=14|issue=4|pages=460–465|doi=10.1016/0009-2614(72)80240-9|bibcode=1972CPL....14..460G}}</ref> These two states have a repulsive range of distances with a maximum around 300 pm, where if the excited atoms approach, they have to overcome an energy barrier.<ref name=Guber72/> The singlet state A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>u</sub> is very unstable with a lifetime only nanoseconds long.<ref>{{cite arxiv|last1=Carter|first1=F.W.|last2=Hertel|first2=S.A.|last3=Rooks|first3=M.J.|last4=McClintock|first4=P.V.E.|last5=McKinsey|first5=D.N.|last6=Prober|first6=D.E.|title=Calorimetric observation of single He∗ 2 excimers in a 100 mK He bath|arxiv=1605.00694v1|date=4 May 2016}}</ref>
The spectrum of the He<sub>2</sub> excimer contains bands due to a great number of lines due to transitions between different rotation rates and vibrational states, combined with different electronic transitions. The lines can be grouped into P, Q and R branches. But the even numbered rotational levels do not have Q branch lines, due to both nuclei being spin 0. Numerous electronic states of the molecule have been studied, including [[Rydberg state]]s with the number of the shell up to 25.<ref name=Panock80>{{cite journal|last1=Panock|first1=R.|last2=Freeman|first2=R.R.|last3=Storz|first3=R.H.|last4=Miller|first4=Terry A.|title=Observation of laser driven transitions to high rydberg states of He2|journal=Chemical Physics Letters|date=September 1980|volume=74|issue=2|pages=203–206|doi=10.1016/0009-2614(80)85142-6|bibcode=1980CPL....74..203P}}</ref>
Helium discharge lamps produce [[vacuum ultraviolet]] radiation from helium molecules. When high energy protons hit helium gas it also produces UV emission at around 600 Å by the decay of excited highly vibrating molecules of He<sub>2</sub> in the A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state to the ground state.<ref name=Hill/> The UV radiation from excited helium molecules is used in the pulsed discharge ionization detector (PDHID) which is capable of detecting the contents of mixed gases at levels below parts per billion.<ref name=Cai13>{{cite journal|last1=Cai|first1=Huamin|last2=Stearns|first2=Stanley D.|title=Pulsed discharge helium ionization detector with multiple combined bias/collecting electrodes for gas chromatography|journal=Journal of Chromatography A|date=April 2013 |volume=1284|pages=163–173|doi=10.1016/j.chroma.2013.01.100}}</ref>
The [[Hopfield continuum]] is a band of ultraviolet light between 600 and 1000 Å in wavelength formed by photodissociation of helium molecules.<ref name=Hill>{{cite journal |last1=Hill|first1=Peter|title=Ultraviolet continua of helium molecules|journal=Physical Review A|date=November 1989|volume=40|issue=9|pages=5006–5016|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.40.5006|bibcode=1989PhRvA..40.5006H}}</ref>
One mechanism for formation of the helium molecules is firstly a helium atom becomes excited with one electron in the 2<sup>1</sup>S orbital. This excited atom meets two other non excited helium atoms in a three body association and reacts to form a A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> state molecule with maximum vibration and a helium atom.<ref name=Hill/>
Helium molecules in the quintet state <sup>5</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>g</sub> can be formed by the reaction of two spin polarised helium atoms in He(2<sup>3</sup>S<sub>1</sub>) states. This molecule has a high energy level of 20 eV. The highest vibration level allowed is v=14.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Beams|first1=Timothy J.|last2=Peach|first2=Gillian|last3=Whittingham|first3=Ian B.|title=Spin-dipole-induced lifetime of the least-bound <sup>5</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>g</sub> state of He(2<sup>3</sup>S<sub>1</sub>)+He(2<sup>3</sup>S<sub>1</sub>)|journal=Physical Review A|date=18 July 2006|volume=74|issue=1|pages=014702|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.74.014702|bibcode=2006PhRvA..74a4702B|arxiv=physics/0604189}}</ref>
In [[liquid helium]] the excimer forms a solvation bubble. In a <sup>3</sup>d state a He{{su|b=2|p=*}} molecule is surrounded by a bubble 12.7 Å in radius at [[atmospheric pressure]]. When pressure is increased to 24 atmospheres the bubble radius shrinks to 10.8 Å. This changing bubble size causes a shift in the fluorescence bands.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bonifaci|first1=Nelly|last2=Li|first2=Zhiling|last3=Eloranta|first3=Jussi|last4=Fiedler|first4=Steven L.|title=Interaction of Helium Rydberg State Molecules with Dense Helium|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry A|date=4 November 2016|doi=10.1021/acs.jpca.6b08412|bibcode=2016JPCA..120.9019B}}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" !state !K ! electronic angular momentum Λ !electronic spin S !Hund's coupling case !type !energy !dissociation energy eV !length pm !vibration levels ! |- |A<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub> ||1,3,5,7 || || || ||singlet|| ||2.5||103.9 |- |B<sup>1</sup>Π<sub>g</sub> || || || || ||singlet|| || |- |C<sup>1</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub> ||0,2,4,6 || || || ||singlet|| || |- |a<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>u</sub>||1,3,5,7 || || || ||triplet|| |- |b<sup>3</sup>Π<sub>g</sub>|| || || || ||triplet|| |- |c<sup>3</sup>Σ<sub>g</sub>||0,2,4,6 ||0 ||1 ||b ||triplet|| |- |<sup>5</sup>Σ<sup>+</sup><sub>g</sub> || || || || ||quintet|| || |}
==Use== The dihelium excimer is an important component in the helium discharge lamp.
A second use of dihelium ion is in ambient ionization techniques using low temperature plasma. In this helium atoms are excited, and then combine to yield the dihelium ion. The He<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> goes on to react with N<sub>2</sub> in the air to make N<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup>. These ions react with a sample surface to make positive ions that are used in [[mass spectroscopy]]. The plasma containing the helium dimer can be as low as 30 °C in temperature, and this reduces heat damage to samples.<ref name="SeróNúñez2016">{{cite journal|last1=Seró|first1=R.|last2=Núñez|first2=Ó.|last3=Moyano|first3=E.|title=Ambient Ionisation–High-Resolution Mass Spectrometry|volume=71|year=2016|pages=51–88|issn=0166-526X|doi=10.1016/bs.coac.2016.01.003|journal=Comprehensive Analytical Chemistry|series=Comprehensive Analytical Chemistry|isbn=9780444635723}}</ref>
==Clusters== He<sub>2</sub> has been shown to form van der Waals compounds with other atoms forming bigger clusters such as <sup>24</sup>MgHe<sub>2</sub> and <sup>40</sup>CaHe<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Liu|first1=Min-min|last2=Han|first2=Hui-li|last3=Li|first3=Cheng-bin|last4=Gu|first4=Si-hong|title=Binding energies and geometry of the <sup>24</sup>Mg-He<sub>2</sub> and <sup>40</sup>Ca-He<sub>2</sub> triatomic systems |journal=Physical Review A|date=October 2013|volume=88|issue=4|pages=042503|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.88.042503|bibcode=2013PhRvA..88d2503L}}</ref>
The [[helium trimer|helium-4 trimer]] (<sup>4</sup>He<sub>3</sub>), a cluster of three helium atoms, is predicted to have an excited state which is an [[Efimov state]].<ref name=Kolg10>{{Cite journal|last1=Kolganova|first1=Elena A.|title=Helium Trimer in the Framework of Faddeev Approach|url=https://sts-karelia09.jinr.ru/publish/Pepan/2010-v41/v-41-7/27-kol.pdf|accessdate=28 February 2015|pages=1108–1110|date=26 Nov 2010|journal=Physics of Particles and Nuclei|volume=41|issue=7|doi=10.1134/S1063779610070282|bibcode=2010PPN....41.1108K}}</ref><ref name=kolg11>{{cite journal|last1=Kolganova|first1=E. A.|last2=Motovilov|first2=A. K.|last3=Sandhas|first3=W.|title=The 4He Trimer as an Efimov System|journal=Few-Body Systems|date=4 May 2011 |volume=51|issue=2–4|pages=249–257|doi=10.1007/s00601-011-0233-x|arxiv=1104.1989|bibcode=2011FBS....51..249K}}</ref> This has been confirmed experimentally in 2015.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kunitski|first1=Maksim|last2=Zeller|first2=Stefan|last3=Voigtsberger|first3=Jörg|last4=Kalinin|first4=Anton|last5= Schmidt|first5=Lothar Ph. H.|last6=Schöffler|first6=Markus|last7=Czasch|first7=Achim|last8=Schöllkopf|first8=Wieland|last9=Grisenti|first9=Robert E.|last10=Jahnke|first10=Till|last11=Blume|first11=Dörte|last12=Dörner|first12=Reinhard|title=Observation of the Efimov state of the helium trimer |journal=Science|date=May 2015|volume=348|issue=6234|pages=551–555|doi=10.1126/science.aaa5601|pmid=25931554|bibcode=2015Sci...348..551K|arxiv=1512.02036}}</ref>
==Cage== Two helium atoms can fit inside larger [[fullerene]]s, including [[C70 fullerene|C<sub>70</sub>]] and [[C84 fullerene|C<sub>84</sub>]]. These can be detected by the [[Helium-3 nuclear magnetic resonance|nuclear magnetic resonance of <sup>3</sup>He]] having a small shift, and by mass spectrometry. C<sub>84</sub> with enclosed helium can contain 20% He<sub>2</sub>@C<sub>84</sub>, whereas C<sub>78</sub> has 10% and C<sub>76</sub> has 8%. The larger cavities are more likely to hold more atoms.<ref name=wang000>{{cite journal|last1=Wang|first1=Guan-Wu|last2=Saunders|first2=Martin|last3=Khong|first3=Anthony|last4=Cross|first4=R. James|title=A New Method for Separating the Isomeric C<sub>84</sub> Fullerenes|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|date=April 2000|volume=122|issue=13|pages=3216–3217|doi=10.1021/ja994270x}}</ref> Even when the two helium atoms are placed closely to each other in a small cage, there is no chemical bond between them.<ref name=cerpa000>{{cite journal|last1=Cerpa|first1=Erick|last2=Krapp|first2=Andreas|last3=Flores-Moreno|first3=Roberto|last4=Donald|first4=Kelling J.|last5=Merino|first5=Gabriel|title=Influence of Endohedral Confinement on the Electronic Interaction between He atoms: A He<sub>2</sub>@C<sub>20</sub>H<sub>20</sub> Case Study|journal=Chemistry: A European Journal|date=9 February 2009|volume=15|issue=8|pages=1985–1990|doi=10.1002/chem.200801399}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Krapp|first1=Andreas|last2=Frenking|first2=Gernot|title=Is This a Chemical Bond? A Theoretical Study of Ng2@C60 (Ng=He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe)|journal=Chemistry: A European Journal|date=5 October 2007|volume=13|issue=29|pages=8256–8270|doi=10.1002/chem.200700467}}</ref> The presence of two He atoms in a C<sub>60</sub> fullerene cage is only predicted to have a small effect on the reactivity of the fullerene.<ref name=osuna009>{{cite journal |last1=Osuna|first1=SÃlvia|last2=Swart|first2=Marcel|last3=SolÃ|first3=Miquel|title=Reactivity and Regioselectivity of Noble Gas Endohedral Fullerenes Ng@C<sub>60</sub> and Ng<sub>2</sub>@C<sub>60</sub>(Ng=He-Xe)|journal=Chemistry: A European Journal|date=7 December 2009 |volume=15|issue=47|pages=13111–13123|doi=10.1002/chem.200901224|url=http://iqc.udg.es/articles/pdf/iqc677.pdf}}</ref> The effect is to have electrons withdrawn from the endohedral helium atoms, giving them a slight positive charge to produce He<sub>2</sub><sup>δ+</sup>, (δ a small value), which have a stronger bond than uncharged helium atoms.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kryachko|first1=Eugene S.|last2=Nikolaienko|first2=Tymofii Yu.|title=He2@C 60 : Thoughts of the concept of a molecule and of the concept of a bond in quantum chemistry|journal=International Journal of Quantum Chemistry|date=15 July 2015|volume=115|issue=14|pages=859–867|doi=10.1002/qua.24916}}</ref> However, by the Löwdin definition there is a bond present.<ref name="dolg"/>
The two helium atoms inside the C<sub>60</sub> cage are separated by 1.979 Å and the distance from a helium atom to the carbon cage is 2.507 Å. The charge transfer gives 0.011 electron charge units to each helium atom. There should be at least 10 vibrational levels for the He-He pair.<ref name="dolg">{{cite journal |last1=Dolgonos |first1=G. A. |last2=Kryachko |first2=E. S. |last3=Nikolaienko |first3=T. Yu |title=До питання Не–Не зв’язку у ендоедральному фулерені Не2@C60 (On the Problem of He–He Bond in the Endohedral Fullerene He2@C60)|journal=Ukrainian Journal of Physics |date=18 June 2018 |volume=63 |issue=4 |pages=288–288 |url=https://ujp.bitp.kiev.ua/index.php/ujp/article/view/2018005 |language=en |issn=2071-0194}}{{open access}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{cite web|publisher=NIST|date=November 1976|url=http://webbook.nist.gov/cgi/cbook.cgi?ID=C12184984&Units=SI&Mask=1000#Diatomic|title=Dihelium}} *{{cite journal|last1=Jahnke|first1=T|title=Interatomic and intermolecular Coulombic decay: the coming of age story|journal=Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics|date=28 April 2015|volume=48|issue=8|pages=082001|doi=10.1088/0953-4075/48/8/082001|bibcode=2015JPhB...48h2001J}} *{{cite journal|last1=Sprecher|first1=D.|last2=Liu|first2=J.|last3=Krähenmann|first3=T.|last4=Schäfer|first4=M.|last5=Merkt|first5=F.|title=High-resolution spectroscopy and quantum-defect model for the gerade triplet np and nf Rydberg states of He2|journal=The Journal of Chemical Physics|date=14 February 2014|volume=140|issue=6|pages=064304|doi=10.1063/1.4864002|pmid=24527912|bibcode=2014JChPh.140f4304S}} spectrum of He<sub>2</sub>
{{Noble gas compounds}} {{diatomicelements}}
[[Category:Helium]] [[Category:Van der Waals molecules]] [[Category:Homonuclear diatomic molecules]] [[Category:Helium compounds]] [[Category:Dimers (chemistry)]]

[[Image:PtF6.png|thumb|upright=0.75|[[Platinum hexafluoride]], the building block of hexafluoroplatinates.]] A '''hexafluoroplatinate''' is a chemical compound which contains the hexafluoroplatinate {{chem2|PtF6(-)}} [[fluoroanion|anion]]. It is produced by combining substances with [[platinum hexafluoride]].
==Examples of hexafluoroplatinates==
* [[Dioxygenyl hexafluoroplatinate]] (O<sub>2</sub>PtF<sub>6</sub>), containing the rare [[dioxygenyl]] [[oxycation]]. * [[Xenon hexafluoroplatinate]] ("XePtF<sub>6</sub>"), the first [[noble gas compound]] ever synthesised. (The Xe<sup>+</sup> ion in XePtF<sub>6</sub> is unstable, being a [[Radical (chemistry)|radical]]; as a result, XePtF<sub>6</sub> itself is unstable and quickly [[disproportionation|disproportionates]] into XeFPtF<sub>5</sub>, XeFPt<sub>2</sub>F<sub>11</sub>, and Xe<sub>2</sub>F<sub>3</sub>PtF<sub>6</sub>.)<ref>Holleman, A. F.; Wiberg, E. "Inorganic Chemistry" Academic Press: San Diego, 2001. {{ISBN|0-12-352651-5}}.</ref>
==See also== * [[Hexachloroplatinate]]
