revision.text:
{{Infobox mineral | name = Yttrium iron garnet | category = Synthetic mineral | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = Wiki-YIG.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | formula = Y<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>2</sub>(FeO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> or Y<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub> | molweight = 737.94<ref name=AmElements/> | color = Green<ref name=AmElements/> | habit = | system = | twinning = | cleavage = | fracture = | mohs = | luster = | polish = | refractive = | opticalprop = | birefringence = | dispersion = | pleochroism = | fluorescence= | absorption = | streak = | gravity = | density = 5.11 g/cm3<ref name=AmElements/> | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = | other = [[Ferrimagnetism|Ferrimagnetic material]] }} '''Yttrium iron garnet''' ('''YIG''') is a kind of synthetic [[garnet]], with chemical composition {{Yttrium}}<sub>3</sub>{{Iron}}<sub>2</sub>(Fe{{Oxygen}}<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, or Y<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub>. It is a [[ferrimagnetic]] material<ref name=AmElements>{{cite web | url = http://www.americanelements.com/yttrium-iron-garnet.html | title = Yttrium Iron Garnet - YIG | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | website = American Elements | access-date = April 1, 2015}}</ref> with a [[Curie temperature]] of 560 [[kelvin|K]].<ref name=Cherepanov>{{cite web | url = https://www.weizmann.ac.il/lvov/Texts-Online/012_Phys-Reps_Saga-IYG.pdf | title = The Saga of YIG: Spectra, Thermodynamics, Interaction and Relaxation of Magnons in a Complex Magnet |author1=Vladimir Cherepanov |author2=Igor Kolokolov |author3=Victor L'Vov |last-author-amp=yes | journal = Physics Reports | volume = 229 | number = 3 | date = 1993 | pages = 84–144 | access-date = April 1, 2015}}</ref> YIG may also be known as yttrium ferrite garnet, or as iron yttrium oxide or yttrium iron oxide, the latter two names usually associated with powdered forms.<ref name=AZONano>{{cite web | url = http://www.azonano.com/article.aspx?ArticleID=3344 | title = Yttrium Iron Oxide / Yttrium Ferrite (Y3Fe5O12) Nanoparticles – Properties, Applications | date = September 10, 2013 | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | website = AZoNano.com | access-date = April 1, 2015}}</ref>
In YIG, the five iron(III) ions occupy two [[octahedral]] and three [[tetrahedral]] sites, with the yttrium(III) ions coordinated by eight oxygen ions in an irregular cube. The iron ions in the two coordination sites exhibit different [[spin (physics)|spins]], resulting in [[magnetic]] behavior.<ref name=Cherepanov/> By substituting specific sites with [[rare earth elements]], for example, interesting magnetic properties can be obtained.<ref name=Goulon>{{cite web | url = http://m.iopscience.iop.org/1367-2630/14/6/063001/pdf/1367-2630_14_6_063001.pdf | title = Site-selective couplings in x-ray-detected magnetic resonance spectra of rare-earth-substituted yttrium iron garnets |author1=J Goulon |author2=A Rogalev |author3=F Wilhelm |author4=G Goujon |author5=A Yaresko |author6=Ch Brouder |author7=J Ben Youssef |last-author-amp=yes | journal = New Journal of Physics | volume = 14 | date = 2012| pages = 1–30 | access-date = April 2, 2015}}</ref>
YIG has a high [[Verdet constant]] which results in the [[Faraday effect]],<ref name = Grattan>{{cite book |editor1=K.T.V. Grattan |editor2=B.T. Meggitt | date = 1999 | title = Optical Fiber Sensor Technology: Volume 3: Applications and Systems | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=1HmAz8L2qnYC&pg=PA214 | publisher = Springer Science & Business Media| pages = 214–215 | isbn = 9780412825705 | access-date = April 2, 2015}}</ref> high [[Q factor]] in [[microwave]] frequencies,<ref name = Belov>{{cite book |author1=Leonid Alekseevich Belov |author2=Sergey M. Smolskiy |author3=Viktor Neofidovich Kochemasov |last-author-amp=yes | date = 2012 | title = Handbook of RF, Microwave, and Millimeter-wave Components | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=bHhYjINB6KMC&pg=PA150 | publisher = Artech House | page = 150 | isbn = 9780412825705 | access-date = April 2, 2015}}</ref> low absorption of [[infrared]] wavelengths down to 1200 nm,<ref name = Sirohi>{{cite book | author = Rajpal S. Sirohi | date = 1990 | title = Optical Components, Systems and Measurement Techniques | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=pXwG5Z9pfk0C&pg=PA80 | publisher = CRC Press | page = 80 | isbn = 9780824783952 | access-date = April 2, 2015}}</ref> and very small [[linewidth]] in [[electron spin resonance]]. These properties make it useful for MOI (magneto optical imaging) applications in [[superconductor]]s.<ref name=Oslo>{{cite web | url = http://www.mn.uio.no/fysikk/english/research/groups/amks/superconductivity/mo/ | title = Magneto-Optical Imaging of Superconductors | author = <!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | publisher = Department of Physics, University of Oslo | date = November 30, 2010 | access-date = April 2, 2015}}</ref>
YIG is used in [[microwave]], [[acoustics|acoustic]], [[optical]], and [[magnetooptics|magneto-optical]] applications, e.g. microwave [[YIG filter]]s, or acoustic [[transmitter]]s and [[transducer]]s.<ref name=Alamos>{{cite web | url = http://periodic.lanl.gov/39.shtml | title = Periodic Table of Elements: Yttrium | author =<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> | publisher = Los Alamos National Laboratory | access-date = April 1, 2015}}</ref> It is transparent for light [[wavelength]]s over 600 nm. It also finds use in [[solid-state laser]]s in [[Faraday rotator]]s, in [[data storage device|data storage]], and in various [[nonlinear optics]] applications.<ref>Holm, U., Sohlstrom, H., & Brogardh, T. (1984). "YIG-Sensor Design for Fiber Optical Magnetic-Field Measurements". Proceedings of the Society of Photo-Optical Instrumentation Engineers, 514, 333–336.</ref>
